e4: Switching to the new, unbiased reporting policy would not only align with legal standards and ethical business practices, thereby reducing potential legal liabilities, but also strengthen investor trust. Over time, this should lead to a more robust and positive market perception of the company, despite potential short-term volatility as investors adjust. Communicating this change effectively to ensure all investors are fully aware and understand the implications is crucial to mitigate any temporary confusion or disadvantages.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should be transparent, accurate, and honest, providing all investors with the same information to make well-informed decisions. It should comply with regulatory standards to prevent legal issues. Additionally, it should include clear communication strategies, especially when there are significant changes in reporting practices, to ensure that all stakeholders understand the financial health of the company without any biases or misleading adjustments.
e6: How will the transition to the new, unbiased reporting policy be communicated to the investors, especially the retail ones, to ensure understanding and to maintain their trust? Additionally, what measures are in place to monitor the market's reaction to this change, and how will the company respond to any negative impacts in the short-term investor sentiment?
